tool.name: Find-seq
tool.description: Align your nucleotide sequences to rice variety-representative genomes
tool.command: #if str($reference.source) == "history": mkdir index_dir && ln -s $reference.own_file index_dir/genome.fa && blat index_dir/genome.fa '$query' -maxIntron='$maxIntron' -tileSize='$tile' -out=$outformat '$output' && rm -rf index_dir #else: blat '$reference.index.fields.path' '$query' -maxIntron='$maxIntron' -tileSize='$tile' -out=$outformat '$output' #end if

param.name: query
param.label: Query FASTA file to align against rice genome of choice

param.name: source
param.label: Select a built-in rice genome/gene database or use a multi-FASTA data from your history?
param.help: Built-in rice genomes are representative of important rice variety groups
param.option: Use a multiFASTA from the history

param.name: index
param.label: Select reference genome
param.help: If your genome of interest is not listed, contact Rice Galaxy team!

validator.message: No indexes are available for the selected input dataset

param.name: index
param.label: Select reference database
param.help: If your genome of interest is not listed, contact Rice Galaxy team!

validator.message: No indexes are available for the selected input dataset

param.name: tile
param.label: size of match that triggers an alignment(between 8 - 12 allowed)

param.name: outformat
param.label: Format for alignment output
param.option: NCBI BLAST tabular format with comments

tool.help:
.. class:: infomark
**Find-seq - what it does**
Find-seq is a specialized alignment tool to find the location of your sequences of interest in the most recent Nipponbare build, and the 4 published rice genomes (IR64, N22, Azucena, Nipponbare)
It uses blat_ as alignment engine. The default parameters of blat should work fine for rice genomes.
.. _blat: http://users.soe.ucsc.edu/~kent/
After identifying the scaffold/contig region aligning to your query sequence, you could extract the subsequence from the rice genome you chose using the Get-subseq tool.
